Award.AwardTitle: CRII: CHS: Transition Resilience: Navigating Invisible Crises with ICTs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
This research focuses on how veterans returning home from war use information and communication technologies (ICTs), such as social and mobile media, to manage invisible crises in transition - those unexpected or unusual dislocations that challenge our ordinary means for solving problems. These technologies can improve peoples' resilience to disruptions, but at present there is a lack of deep and systematic knowledge about how ICTs enable resiliency, and this research aims to address this gap. A more empirically situated understanding of how transitions happen and how ICTs are used can provide the basis for improving the designs of technologies, advancing training and education for transition, and influencing policy. The broader impacts of the proposed work include: (1) Developing guidelines in support of training, education and policies to support veterans' transitions to their non-war life, which can also be applied to other groups undergoing transitions; and (2) Contributing to the development of new ICT-enabled tools to help people detect, make sense of and navigate an array of invisible crises.

The case of US veterans will yield valuable insights in understanding ICT-enabled resilience, as their transition is long-term, their experience often involves several crises at once, and institutional support to help them regain normalcy post-service is often poor. The following questions will guide the inquiry: How can ICTs help people manage and adapt to their new situations? How do people decide which ICT resources to use? How do people transact support, both social and informational, through different ICTs? How are online support spaces sustained? What requirements and designs for new ICTs could be identified to support transition resilience? In pursuit of answers, the research combines several periods of intense data collection that rely on semi-structured interviews and observations of online data, such as what is communicated through social media. A participatory design and diary study effort will inform the initial development and evaluation of a new ICT that empowers veterans via the ability to detect, make sense of and navigate invisible crises.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To understand how people use ICTs to build resilience while in transition, the research from this grant focused on the experiences of United States (US) military veterans as they re-integrate into civilian society (Semaan, Britton, and Dosono, 2016; Semaan, Britton, and Dosono, 2017). Veterans are a unique case to explore resilience in that they face several transitions at once; after returning home, many veterans have to change occupations, re-adjust to family life, manage PTSD, and more.  Importantly, these issues are all connected to identity crises caused by the lack of continuity between military and civilian social structures. When veterans return home post-service, they leave a highly structured collectivist military culture and enter the highly unstructured and individualistic civilian world.

Through an initial study exploring the transition experiences of veterans, my students and I found that veterans demonstrate resilience through their use of ICTs to develop identity awareness. Through online activities veterans connect with other veterans and, via these connections, develop a “big picture” understanding of unfamiliar rules and norms and receive support when navigating civil society (Semaan, Britton, and Dosono, 2016). For example, veterans use social media to learn how to act and present themselves in real world contexts so that they can better fit in at home, at work, or in public spaces across the several phases of transition. They also use social media platforms to engage in rapid response work, such as for suicide mediation.

Following up on this original study, we recognized that veterans were having trouble talking about, or disclosing, the issues they were facing. We found that veterans have been resilient through their uses of ICTs as a means to disclose struggles while in transition (Semaan, Britton, and Dosono, 2017). We found that the culture of hyper-masculinity learned and performed during military service leads to challenges to disclosure, negatively impacting how military veterans navigate the transition back into civil society. However, veterans were able to use online platforms to navigate the challenges limiting disclosure and connect with supportive resources, especially when they observed other veterans disclosing struggles of their own. This is significant given that research suggests that disclosure—making struggles known—and the connection with sympathetic others are critical during periods of transition.

In understanding the veteran transition experience, I also designed new ICTs to help people manage and navigate chronic disruption to their routine lives. My empirical work suggests that veterans often seek to reconnect with the values of military culture while in transition (Semaan, Britton, and Dosono, 2016). For example, one central cultural feature instilled through the military is camaraderie. Military members are inculcated with a strong sense of “brotherhood” and “sisterhood” whereby they develop strong ties with their peers. When veterans leave the military, this camaraderie is missing and they experience a great sense of loss (Semaan, 2019). As such, I designed a mobile mental health platform that draws on veteran logics of camaraderie to enable veterans to reconnect with and provide peer mentorship to others. This system was designed to promote collaborative, or camaraderie-oriented, care in support of managing and recovering from a range of issues, e.g. PTSD and anger management (Franco, Hooyer, Rizia, Patwary, Armstrong, Semaan, Kuziemsky, and Ahmed, 2016).

Moreover, as a means of further helping veterans manage and make sense of the many invisible crises they face while in transition, I designed and developed a prototype wearable device and visual dashboard that empowers veterans in detecting, making sense of, and managing invisible crises (Bratt, Semaan, Britton, Dosono, and Franco, 2017). One primary use for our system is to empower veterans in the self-management of PTSD. PTSD is an avoidance-based disorder whereby people often avoid situations when those situations remind them of previous negative experiences. For example, in our study we found that veterans often avoid crowds when they have previously encountered an improvised explosive device (IED). Our system allows veterans to document PTSD triggers (e.g. crowds and locations) as they go about their routine lives, provides them with opportunities to reflect on these experiences individually and collaboratively, and gives them mechanisms for managing these experiences on a moment-to-moment basis (e.g. wellness techniques), in an effort to reduce avoidance and establish patterns of action that reflect their current reality.
